text: From a sign reading "Pleasant Valley Dream Homes", a pict postcard boulevard of mini mansions curves into infinity. Each home is brand new. Each has the same size lawn, the shrubs, the same satellite dish. Each has an indistinguishable car parked in the driveway. All the homes have Christmas decorations, Christmas trees with baubles, lights and Christmas stars sitting proudly the top. The doors have Christmas wreaths. The sheen of a recent rainfall makes all the surfaces gli in the lights. We halt outside one house. 2

This home too seems perfect until we notice the Christmas star has fallen from the top of the tree and lies reflect itself in a puddle on the wet lawn. Suddenly we hear the sound of wings fluttering and see an among the branches of the Christmas tree. It rises from t tree then swoops down to the lawn where it sweeps a mouse from the grass. The owl then soars off, casting a magnifi shadow of her wings across the house, and disappears with it's prey into the woods behind. Curtains part at a downstairs window. The silhouette of a appears bathed in the blue glow of a computer screen. He draws the curtains once again and disappears. 3

We sneak between curtain and window ledge into a home off fitted out with a flat screen TV and a computer. KENNETH, a forty something ex-jock with a once handsome f pours a beer into a crystal brandy glass. Kenneth's eyes glued to the computer screen where stock numbers scroll endlessly down. He highlights a set of numbers and stands abruptly from his chair elated.
Yes!
Steps back onto a A CHILD'S DOLL, crushing it underfoot. ebullient mood changes quickly.
Damn! DELLA!

The sound of footsteps are followed by the door opening. DELLA peers into the room. She's a diminutive blonde in h thirties with fine features and a fading Southern accent. She's pulling a coat on over a white shirt and jeans. She sees the broken doll.
SHOOT, KENNETH! That's Tammi's favorite doll.
She walks in, picks up the doll and tries to fix its squa face. He turns back to the computer guiltily, takes a sip beer.
You should just swear properly and get it over with. Do you think the kids don't know what you mean?
Close up, his face is ruddy - the face of someone who dri too much. He turns back towards her. She ignores him, continues to try fix the doll. His eyes linger on her coa
Going out again? What is it tonight? Auto Mechanics for Dummies? The bored housewives' reading group?
He averts his eyes back to the screen then turns back to at her once more.
I got a new one for you.
He smiles sardonically.
Group therapy for women who always have the curse. There's a Tuesday night class at the Pleasant Valley Episcopalian.
Kenneth clearly thinks he's funny. Della glares a warning him and bites her lip to stop a vitriolic response escapi from her mouth.
I'm going to the mall for wrapping paper.
A trail of kids mess in the hallway behind Della catches Kenneth's eye.
What do you do all day, Della honey? Cause it sure isn't keeping house. This place is an eyesore. I'm mortgaged up to the eyeballs for this?
His sad eyes meet hers in confrontation. Della, determine not to engage, averts hers. Kenneth, unable to contain himself, faces her.
I mean it's not like you're at some salon fancying up your hair or nails like the other men's wives.
He lifts a strand of her limp fair hair and lets it drop, looks right in her tired face.
The last time I saw you wearing something sexy was our engagement party. God, Della, you used to be hot!
She bites her lip again, but this time to try stop the te He turns away, in an attempt to conceal his own sadness. She walks away clutching the doll.
Put the twins to bed by eight. Give them a chocolate cookie with their milk.
Jesus, Della. Della honey, I'm sorry.

But she's already left the room. He watches her pick up a of car keys from a dresser in the dimly lit hallway. Her knuckles are white as she clenches her fingers around the Kenneth turns back to his computer. 4

Della climbs the stairs. Framed photographs on the wall t the public story of her life. The engagement to Kenneth, their wedding, the birth of the twins, Kenneth's graduati Kenneth as a sixth grade football star, Della on the farm Ohio with her horse, a really young Della playing basebal with her father. We linger on a photo of a very pretty tw something Della in a little black dress. 5

TERRI and TAMMI are seven year old twins with the delicat blue eyed blonde looks of their Mother. Della stands in the doorway and watches them. Tammi is lying on her girlish bed drawing with crayons. Terri's toy dinosaurs are destroying Tammi's heirloom dol house, starting with the furniture. She steps into the room.
Mommy can I get an American Girl for Christmas?
I want a raptor dinosaur, Mommy.
You better leave Santa a note. It's only three days until Christmas.
She gives them each a kiss, breathing in their scent she loves so much.
Where are you going, Mommy? Scene 5 Page 5
The Mall. One chocolate cookie each and then Daddy will read you a bedtime story.
Daddy's stories are lame. I want you to read us a story.
Yeah Mommy, the one about the pirates.
No, the cowgirls. Diamond Lil and Slingshot Kitty.
Tomorrow night I'll read you the best bedtime story in the whole world. I promise.
Della gives them a little wave and turns to leave.
I'll check in on you both when I get back. (beat) To make sure you're sleeping.

She smiles. Terri's already turned back to his dinosaurs. Tammi runs toward her and gives her the drawing she's bee working on. It's a drawing of a stick figure family holdi hands. The words "Mommy, we love you" are written across cloudy night sky like big stars.
Thank you, Tammi, it's wonderful.
Della doesn't have time to look at it properly so she fol the drawing up and puts it in her pocket. She kisses Tamm again and turns to leave. Tammi's eyes follow her mother she walks away. 6
Della checks her watch and hurries down the stairs. 7

She sits on the bottom stair to pull on a pair of boots. boots are well worn but polished to a gleam. Behind her, an antique grandfather clock strikes seven p. The sound of gun shots fades in from the TV in Kenneth's office. 8
Della collects a packet of cookies from a cabinet. She lo at the pile of dirty dinner dishes in the sink then looks away. 9
Della leaves the cookies at the bottom of the stairs and opens the front door. The TV blares out some action flick from Kenneth's ajar door.

Della is met by a blast of cold evening air and the eerie silence of the suburbs. She closes the door softly behind and rushes along the path to the driveway where the famil black Ford Explorer is parked. She CHIRPS the remote and quickly climbs in. 11
Della inserts the key and turns it in the lock.    The ca sputters in defiance against the cold night.
Frick!
The car sputters again.
C'MON...

With a massive exertion, the car engine turns over and th vehicle starts. She sighs with relief. She turns the heat up high and warms her hands at the ven pauses to look at her home through the car window. For a second, in an upstairs window, she sees a reflection of Tammi. She smiles, then looks at the house and lawn and the Christmas tree. She notices the fallen star, is about to out of the car to retrieve it, but decides it's too cold. A shadow creeps across her face as she pulls the stick in reverse and backs up. 12

We follow her as she backs up, pushes into drive and head slowly down the boulevard. The road is empty. All the cars are neatly tucked away in their driveways and it looks like no one's out tonight. S makes a right turn onto. 13
She follows the road as it curves around a long row of endlessly monotonous houses. In the distance, we can see gates of Pleasant valley gated community. 14

She slows down, rolls down her window and swipes a chub c against the security panel. The gates slowly open. She dr through. The gates close behind her. She rolls the window and makes a left turn onto. 15
The road is wider and framed on either side by the high w of gated communities. A Ford Explorer just like hers pass in the opposite direction. 16

Della smiles mysteriously, reaches into the glove compart with her free hand. She pushes aside a bunch of car paper flare, pulls out a check wallet hidden underneath - her secret hiding place for: A nice pack of Marlboros. She smiles again - the smile of secret smoker. She presses the cigarette lighter into the dashboard. The lighter pops out. She tips out a cigarette, sees a sticky note attached to the interior foil. Scrawled in me handwriting are the words - YOU ARE SUPPOSED TO BE QUITTI DELLA HONEY. XOXO KENNETH.
I'll get right on that Kenneth honey. AFTER you stop drinking. Scene 16Page 8
She rips the note off, stuffs it in her purse, lights the cigarette. She inhales deeply.     We see the pleasure written acros face. 17
A few cars pass Della in the night. Their lights are like torches in the suburban wilderness. 18

location: FORD EXPLORER/ EXT. PLEASANT VALLEY DRIVE

text: There is the familiar ring of a cellular phone. Della has programmed one of those "oh so cute" recognizable tunes i it, like the "William Tell overture". Della holds the wheel with one hand and fumbles through h purse with the other. She eventually locates the phone.
Hello?
Della, it's Mary Messina.
Della rolls her eyes.     This is not a welcome call.
Oh, hey.
You okay sweetie?
Sure. How are you?
I'm well.
How'd you get my cell number?
Della balances the phone while she drags on her cigarette
I called Kenneth at the house.
Oh great.   She exhales sharply. Scene 18Page 9
And how'd that go? Did he give you an earful for disturbing his ninety ninth viewing of Lethal Weapon Four? Mary giggles.
Oh Della. Kenneth is always charming. At least to me. The car flashes past the decorated sign for a local schoo Before Della can stop herself, the words are out.
Well, with the way you flaunt your double D boob job at the free fun PTA events that's hardly a surprise. Fortunately for her the phone happens to make a deep meta distortion at that moment.
What was that?
Oh nothing, Mary.
You got lucky with that one. Patricia Ellis says he's the best looking guy in Pleasant Valley.
Well that wouldn't be hard. Mary, do you need something? Cause I gotta go.
Yes, are you going to Tool School tomorrow? Mary giggles at her own joke. Della sighs.    THIS is why she is having her serenity interrupted? Scene 18Page 10
TOOL SCHOOL?, Ouch, Mary. Do It Yourself Mechanics is without a doubt the most interesting thing in my life right now. (Smiles)
I carry my beloved toolbox in the trunk at all times. The desolate road disappears behind Della.    She passes roadside memorial.
I'm just joking, Della. You know me. I pre-paid ten classes and only made it to two. If you are going I could use a ride. I'd hate to miss another class. If Della was going before, she's not now.
Sorry, Mary, I'm skipping this week. Kenneth's parents are coming to stay for Christmas. You know how it is. A red light looms ahead. Della slows.
Oh that's too bad. Maybe Patricia Ellis will be going.
You check with her, Mary.
Merry Christmas. God bless you and your family. Christmas lights outline a few distant houses.
You too. (Under her breath)
Bah Humbug.
Pardon?

Bye, Mary. Della stops at the red light. She clicks off the phone an lets it lay on her lap. She rakes about among a bunch of kids stuff in the back s casts aside, an anorak, mittens, a sock. She finds what she's looking for, a bottle of water, caug on the bar under the passenger seat. It's only a third fu but she takes a sip, recoils from its coldness. The light changes.   She throws the bottle into the back 19
Christmas lights: reindeer, stars, even the American flag the black night. 20
Della picks up the phone and pushes a few keys. She has n dialed enough to make a full phone call when we hear the phone RING on the other side.
Cellular 411 connect. How may I direct your call?
The Learning Academy. Spring Street.

Please hold for that number. Della slows down for another red light. She's at a wide crossroads where the housing development abruptly ends and a wasteland of deforestation begins. A billboard for another new housing development announces "GREEN STREET DREAM HOMES - Investment Opportunities". Waiting for the light at the opposite side of the road fr Della is a car with an animal cadaver strapped to the roo Della tries not to look at it. A recording breaks into the moment just as the light ahea changes to green. Scene 20Page 12
(recording)
Press your pound key now to connect with your request. Della presses the pound key and drives straight ahead.
Learning Academy, this is Meghan.
Hi Meghan.     It's Della Myers.
Oh hey. You calling about Spanish for Beginners? You know that Tom cancelled 'cause of New Year's.
Yes I knew.
Can you hold, I have another call?
Okay. Frustrated, Della turns on the radio.    It is some innoc local ad.

Pleasant Valley Dream Homes. The lowest crime rate in the US. Call 1- 800-SAFE. Della switches stations trying to find something she like She gives up and waits for Meghan to return. The car flas past construction road signs.
Sorry Della ...
Can you leave word for Mike. I'm going to miss tomorrow's Mechanic's class. It's just the one time.
Everyone misses that class at least once. Scene 20Page 13
I guess some people find it boring.
We'll see you the first week in January then?
Yes you will...unless I run off and become an outlaw or something. Meghan giggles. We hear the familiar beep of another call coming in.
I have to go.
Merry Christmas
You too. Della clicks the phone over to the incoming call.
Hello?
Hi Della... it's Cassie. Cassie's voice is almost lost in the din of her surroundi
Where are you? Grand Central Station?
Hold on, I'll take the phone outside. A loud noise appears out of nowhere. 21
The car SCREECHES to a halt. Della almost didn't see it. is at a railroad crossing, the third car in line, and she almost rear-ended the car in front of her.
Just a minute, Della.

I almost rear-ended a car. Cassie? The phone cuts out. The train starts to go laboriously pa Carriage after carriage of brand name building materials new housing developments. Della lights another cigarette. She turns on the radio again, finds a station playing "Th Sound of Silence". The crossing gates go up.   The cars ahead of her start. Della shifts into drive. The phone rings its special tune again.   Della turns the volume of the radio down.
What's up, Cassie?
I'm over at Southeast Plaza. What was it we need to get for Pilates?
Huh? One of those rubber balls, I think. I'm headed over there now. Ran out of Christmas wrapping paper. Would you believe it?
It's hell here tonight. Everyone and their uncle is at the mall. Della's phone makes a loud, distorted noise.
Aw shoot. My cell battery's dying. She rifles about in the passenger seat, leans over to the back, and rifles about there among the kids toys, gives u
Damn, I must have left the charger in the other car. Scene 21Page 15
You want me to pick up something for you while I'm here? Cassie's kind offer almost reduces Della to tears.
No....I'm just. I mean I'm. Oh nothing. The phone beeps again.
Your phone's breaking up Della. I'm not joking when I say it's packed over here.
It can't be that bad? The light up ahead turns amber then red.    Della stops.
Why don't we meet somewhere for a drink?
Sure, but a latte's about the best they can do in this mall.
A latte's fine. Let's meet at the fountain opposite Victoria's Secret. The light changes and Della drives up and over a hill.
Sounds good. The phone beeps again.
My battery's going. I'm a block away. See you in five minutes.

Okay but I won't be able to wait very .... The phone beeps again.   It's over. Della lets it drop onto her lap. She opens the window and flicks out the remains of her cigarette. She waves her ha to fan away the smoke. She closes the window again. She's about to hide her cigarettes again when she changes mind and stuffs them directly into her purse. As the car approaches the cusp of the hill she slows down stare ahead. 22
Southeast Plaza.   The day before Christmas Eve. Hell on Earth. A large, sprawling parking lot full of cars.   Nothing bu cars. A sea of cars. 23
For a second, Della contemplates turning around and leavi The guy in the SUV behind her beeps. She steps on the gas
Okay, okay! Her car careens slowly down hill to the lot. 24

The road spits her out in front of the Mall entrance wher revellers and shoppers are entering and exiting. Della follows several cars down the first long row of par cars. The asphalt is wet from the recent rainfall. Puddles gath in its dents and hollows. She passes car after densely parked car. There isn't a sp in sight. She reaches the end of the row and indicates le turns down the next row, ploughs through a rain puddle wh splashes up onto a MOTHER who's walking her little GIRL a BOY back to their car. The woman shouts at Della.
Watch where you're going! Della rolls down her window. Scene 24Page 17

Sorry! The Mother's weighed down with shopping bags. She glares Della and drags her kids across the aisle in front of her Della sighs, drives down the second aisle. An Escape midway down the row blocks traffic. It's waitin for a Subaru to pull out so it can take the spot. 25
Lucky son of a ..... The Subaru exits the spot slowly. Della taps her impatien fingers against the steering wheel. 26
The Subaru pulls away and the Escape snaps into the empty space. Della continues her journey down to the end of the row. T are no spaces. 27
It dawns on her that parking up close to the entrance jus isn't going to happen. She takes the last puff from the cigarette burning out in the ashtray. 28

Using the side aisle she scoots past row three and four a they all flow one way. At the end of this row a confrontation is brewing. Severa cars block each other. Horns blast. An angry DRIVER screa at another.
If you think you're gonna steal my spot, think again, asshole! 29

Della looks on for a moment at the confrontation. She gri out the stub of her cigarette into the ashtray, slams it closed. Della shakes her head and turns left into row five. Jesus Are there really this many cars in Pleasant Valley? It's brand new Mall and the only one around for miles but this ridiculous. Della reaches the end of row five quickly. She guessed th wouldn't be a spot so she's driving faster. She notices a portly middle aged RENT-A-COP directing tra ahead. She lowers her window.
Hello? The Rent-a-Cop stops directing and approaches the car.
Can I help you?
Do you know where I can definitely find parking?
There's nothing close by. Even the valet's backed up. You might want to try further out. He points off into the distance through the sea of cars.
But be willing to walk. A car waiting behind Della honks its horn loudly and the A-Cop saunters away. Della guns the Ford down row eight. 30
At the end of this row, Della decides to take the Rent-A- Cop's advice. She makes another left at the aisle and ski several more rows. She heads down to the third from last 31
Cars... cars... If she never sees another car it will be soon. Della spies a spot, halfway down the row.
Yes! She guns the engine, gets ready to pull in and is DENIED. Somebody has parked an enormous old gold Plymouth so badl it's taking up TWO spaces.
Unbelievable! She brakes in the nick of time and sighs deeply. She's starting to lose her patience now. 32

With no options left, Della heads down to the very last r More cars fill the spaces. And then - two spots. The last two spots in the car park. They overlook undeveloped land just beyond the mall. Small concrete bumps signify the en each space. 33

Della whips the car into the first one. She sighs with relief as she straightens the car up into the spot. She s for a second trying to calm herself down but it isn't working. She reaches for another cigarette, then, talks herself out of it. She fastens her coat, grabs her purse and opens the door. 34
Steps down from the Ford right into a puddle. The dirty w splashes up onto her pants.

She shakes the boot off and looks over at the mall. It's least a half mile away, glimmering in the distance. She sets off marching across the lot, taking what seems t the most direct route. Maybe she can shake off this mood the time she gets inside. She passes the Plymouth, turns, stares back at it. The ca dirty gold and riddled with rust holes with a vinyl roof that's almost peeled away. She walks up close, tries to decipher the plate, but it's caked with mud. Annoyance rises like bile in her throat. She finds herself reaching into her purse, rummaging for small notebook, then a sharpie. She leans on the car as s writes.

head_text.subj: DEAR JERK, IT'S GREAT YOU COULD USE UP TWO PARKING SPACES
A NIGHT LIKE THIS. EVER HEAR OF THE JOY OF SHARING

text: She scans her words.    Pretty good! Della rips the piece of paper from the notebook, folds th note several times and slides it under the Plymouth's windshield wipers. The driver can't miss it. She smiles. That felt good! Head held high she marches on towards the Mall. The CAMERA pulls up so we can see the mall, see Della marching across the lot, see the crowds of shoppers enter and exiting the mall, and get the feeling that maybe some just saw her. 35
Shoppers are buying freshly felled Christmas trees from a vendor. Della squeezes past and pushes through the mall doors. 36

A wave of heat and Christmas lights hits Della. A wave of nausea follows as she is swallowed by the crowd of last minute shoppers. Distorted muzak versions of Christmas so seep from invisible speakers. Della gets caught up in a line of children waiting to see Santa in his grotto. She squeezes through and makes her w towards the fountain outside of Victoria's Secret. En route she is stopped by a perfume sales lady who spray her wrist with perfume before she has time to protest.
It's a classic revival of Chanel No.5. We have a wonderful Christmas Special on offer at Macy's. She hands Della a sample and flyer.

Thanks. Della arrives at the fountain. A piddling jet of dirty wa gurgles from the mouth of a bored mermaid and streams dow into the shallow pool full of nickels and dimes. She scan the crowd but there's no sign of Cassie. Della sits at the edge of the fountain. She checks her wa then checks out the people milling around in front of Victoria's Secret, where mannequins in skimpy festive underwear are propped seductively in the window displays. Still no sign of Cassie. She's about to make a wish and t a quarter into the fountain when a Red Cross worker shake her "Save the Children" tin at her. Della sticks the quar into the tin instead. 37

Della wanders the aisles of festive colored undies watchi men pick out slinky lingerie for their partners and women examine slim fit underpants and padded bras. She notices a pure silk black teddy, very classic, no fri She lifts it from the rail and holds it against herself i front of the mirror, tries to imagine herself in it. A young SALES ASSISTANT approaches.

It's pure silk, the last one in our classic black label collection. Would you like me to fix you a changing room? Della checks the size tag. It reads 36C, two sizes too bi And the price tag next to it. Ouch! It's expensive for Victoria's Secret.
No thanks. Not my size. She gestures to her small boobs, smiles and hands the ted to the sales assistant. She quickly leaves the shop. 38
Della checks one last time at the fountain for Cassie. Sh tries to dodge the crowd as she makes her way toward a generic coffee shop. Maybe Cassie will be there. 39

Harried women and a few men, clutching bags full of gifts impatient children, stand on line for their favorite drug Della squeezes past them to look for Cassie. Every seat a every booth is full but there's no sign of her friend. Della joins the line. She finds herself biting at her nai a bad habit since childhood. A woman in front of her places an order then moves on to pick up area. Della moves up to the counter to where an OVERWEIGHT SALES ASSISTANT waits on her.
A latte please? She notices some chocolate covered biscotti on the counte
And a chocolate biscotti. She catches sight of herself in the mirror behind the counter. Kenneth's right about one thing, she looks awful
Bitter or Milk chocolate? Seeing herself in the mirror changes her mind about the biscotti.
Forget it, just the coffee.
Name?
Della, two L's.

Four dollars and seventy nine cents. Della pushes the money towards her and waits for her coff When it finally shows up her name is spelled DELA. She si and checks the line for Cassie as she leaves the shop. 40

She passes a hair salon and presses her face to the steam windows. Inside, women are getting their hair styled and their nails manicured at the same time. Della looks down at her bitten nails but just can't bring herself to go inside.
Della, is that you? She turns around to see LYNN MONROE, a pretty, well groom redhead about her age.
Lynn Monroe!
I knew it was you, Della. I haven't seen you since college. You left to marry some handsome jock and we never heard from you again.
Something like that. Do you live around here now?
David and I just bought this divine house in Pleasant Valley. Do you know it? Great for the kids. Della nods but Lynn keeps speaking. Della sips on her lat

It's the first time I've left the doors unlocked since I was a child growing up in the Midwest. David's been promoted to VP of United Motors so it's all happening for us. But enough of me. How are you?
Oh, we have two kids. Twins, Tammi and Terri. Lynn becomes distracted, focusing on her perfect reflecti in the steamy glass.

Why that's fantastic. Listen Della, it's been great talking to you but I have to go get my hair done! David and I are going out tomorrow night for a romantic dinner. I just bought this gorgeous teddy from Victoria's Secret. She opens the bag and Della sees it's the black teddy she eyed earlier. Della smiles.

Hope we bump into each other again soon, sweetie. Merry Christmas She gives Della a fake kiss and rushes into the salon. Della chucks her half finished coffee into a nearby trash and walks on through the Mall. 41

Della enters a pharmacy. She locates the wrapping paper aisle. She sweeps up a bunch of rolls at three for ninety nine cents. She feels the texture of the paper, it's thin looks gaudy so she puts them all back. Instead she select some expensive gold paper with silver embossed stars and matching silver ribbon. She then finds some jolly childre wrapping with Christmas tree designs and a great big red She browses through the aisles of cards. She sees some cu cards for the twins and then arrives at the "To my Darlin Husband at Christmas" section. She opens some of the card and recoils from the sentiments contained inside. She catches a groomed BLONDE HOUSEWIFE staring at her and corrects her facial expression from one of revulsion to a complicit Stepford smile.

It's a pity they don't have any "To a bastard at Christmas" cards. The woman looks at Della like she's a lunatic. Della chuc to herself. She finds the feminine hygiene aisle and picks up a pack regular tampax. She gathers her stuff and carries it to the checkout wher TIRED MAN and his TWO KIDS wait before her on the line. The man tries to remove a snow globe, with a tiny house a Christmas tree inside, from the clutches of his young son The child starts bawling. The man ends up buying the snow globe to placate the child. It's Della's turn. The PHARMACY SALES ASSISTANT smiles.
Perfect timing!
God planned it for Christmas Day just to tick me off.
Thirty dollars and sixty nine cents
She packs Della's stuff into paper bags. Della hands her card over.
Thanks.
Merry Christmas.

It's a lot less crowded now. The melancholy "Home for Christmas" plays. She follows the ladies sign to the entr to the bathroom, only to find an "Out of Order" sign on t door. She sees a cleaning lady in the corridor.
How come the ladies' bathroom is out of order on a night like this?
The one at the other side of the mall is open, Ma'am.

The    cleaning lady disappears through the bathroom door her    cart of cleaning utensils. Della looks down the le the    huge mall and decides she's not even going to try the    other bathroom. She can wait until she gets home. She makes her way towards the exit, pulls her coat in tig and braces herself for the cold front outside. Scene 43Page 26
A group of CAROL SINGERS sing "Silent Night".

Silent Night. Holy Night. All is calm. All is bright. Della listens for a moment. Their voices are clear and bright. Behind them she can see the Christmas tree vendor bag up left over trees. Della's hands start to pinch with the cold. She gathers her bags of wrapping paper and sets off acros the emptying lot. The last of the shoppers rush across th car park to find their cars. It's pretty dark between the pole lamps and the car lights. She slows down at the second aisle for a car to pass, the another. Marches on. A man and his little girl walk past. He nods. Della's eye linger on the little girl. She really wants to get home t the kids. The singers' voices echo faintly through the night.

Holy infant so tender and mild. She walks faster, almost at a dash. Where is her car? Even further out than she remembered, that's for sure. A car alarm goes off in the distance. The alarm stops at last as Della approaches the outer sec of the parking lot.

Shepherds quake at the sight. Glories beam from heaven afar. She cuts between some of the cars in row eight. Zigzags across aisle nine. Notices the Plymouth still parked ahea She stops for a split second. Then approaches. Glances at windshield. The note is gone. Maybe it fell off. She checks the ground around the car. sign of it. She shrugs, who cares anyway? She cuts across the next aisle. It's almost empty. And th one after that. Her Explorer is sandwiched between two ca in this otherwise empty row.

Silent Night. Holy Night She chirps the remote twice and pops the trunk, places th bags inside. She slams the trunk closed and hurries to th drivers' side, climbs in, pulling the door closed behind 44

Della turns the key in the ignition and presses in the lighter. She lights a cigarette and inhales as she lets t car warm up for 30 seconds. She rests the cigarette in the ashtray while she releases hand brake and slips the gear into reverse. The interior her car is suddenly flooded with light from another car's headlights. She glances in the rear view mirror. A car is blocking her.

Good Lord! What now? She steps on the brake and waits for the car to move. But it doesn't. Its headlights flick to full beam blindin her view in her car mirrors. She honks her horn. The car still doesn't move. Della's really angry now. She slips the gearshift into pa and steps out of her car. 45

Della squints in the blinding headlights. The front of th car looks familiar. It's the gold Plymouth! Two unseen car doors click open and clunk shut again. The lights abruptly go out. Della blinks, her eyes try to adjust to the dim mercury illumination from a pole lamp a car lengths away. She uneasily turns back to her car. Scene 45Page 28
I got a gun. It's a young male voice. The statement stops Della dead i her tracks.

How's about I aim it at your pussy first? The words are emphasized by another boy's shrill giggling Della freezes. This can't be happening! Her eyes are adjusting. The glare phantoms drift out to t limit of her peripheral vision and vanish. She sees three boys in front of her, then a fourth, but s doesn't see any gun.

Looking back constantly to the edge of the trees for a si of the boys. Fear drives her further into the woods towards where the trees grow even more densely together. Where there just m be the right place to hide. She stops for a second to catch her breath. The handle of the toolbox has chaffed her right palm. She changes hands. God, that boy Huey! He really died back there. She heard sound of it. The horrific sound of him dying a stupid pointless death. It could have been her. There has to be some way out of this nightmare. Ahead, a dead tree with spectral branches blocks her path She steps around its huge trunk and tangle of roots.

Chuckie's voice drifts towards her.   She ducks down amon roots. Her eyes scan the darkness. No moving shapes nor forms. No sound. No flashlight. Just shadowy clumps of trees. Should she stay put or should she run? Then she sees it. The flashlight weaving through the pine ahead. She pushes further in among the roots, tries to make hers invisible. The flashlight beam sweeps across the forest floor toward her. One set of footsteps crunches through the foilage. She holds still, terrified. The flashlight pauses on the dead tree, the roots. Scene 97Page 57

Della stops breathing. Then, the light sweeps past and on into the woods. She waits until it disappears before stepping out of her hiding place. She creeps back in the opposite direction, figuring if they're in the woods now she should get out. Her eyes search for the construction light, which indicat the edge of the wood. She heads in the direction of the light, painfully aware one noisy footfall could alert her pursuers. She steps between leaves and roots as delicately as a ballet dancer The construction light grows closer. The light abruptly goes out. She stops, eyes desperately searching the trees. She resumes in the direction she was headed. Tries to kee calm. But the woods are impenetrable. Layers of trees and shrub and then more trees. Deep in the cold dark places there a patches of left over snow. She's losing her bearings. 98

Ahead, the chilling sight of four luminous Xs glowing in dark forest almost makes her heart stop. She realizes the crosses are painted on the trunks of several trees, marki them for death. She shivers. 99

She backs up, starts off in the opposite direction. And there it is again. The flashlight sweeping through th trees in the distance. She stops, close to screaming, then when the flashlight disappears, runs off in yet another direction. She slows to take a breath, notices the butts of several cigarettes still smoking in the dirt close to her feet. Scene 99Page 58
(muttering to herself) Shit! Oh Shit!

She trudges on, pushing between the branches, no clue whe she is headed. The further she treads, the quieter it becomes. So quiet can hear her own footfalls and the sound of the trees breathing. Then, she spots the light again, in the distance, shining over the forest. Thank God! She trudges up a slope ahead, clinging onto branches and shrubs to help pull herself up. 100
The light grows closer. She climbs up onto a ledge. A loud noise startles her. It's music. Rap music. Blastin Della pushes her way through to the edge of the trees. Sees.... 101

The woodland ahead slopes down into a clearing, where a h ghetto blaster sits on a pile of felled trees. Young pine about to become Christmas trees. It's blasting out a hip anthem for a dead homie. A construction light illuminates clearing. A ghostly Vinh, head hung low, moves to the music, bottle beer in hand. Propped up against a tree stump sits the body of Huey, ar crossed over his torso, hood pulled up to cover his face. The scene is so surreal that Della is drawn closer. She creeps along the edge of the trees. As she moves, she kicks back on some dirt. It tumbles downhill into the gulch. She freezes. But nobody notices. She slips invisibly between the trees and watches as Toma enters the clearing. Tomas stops and watches Vinh. Vinh continues to get into the music in his solemn Japane punk style. The juxtaposition between the hard core rap m and the serious vibe that Vinh is sending out shows us th this is really important music to him. It's a theatrical tableau - Della overhead, looking down on the clearing. Vinh transfixed by the music. Tomas stone silent, watching Vinh. It plays out for a poignant moment. Like they're all part some spiritual rite about to be consummated. Vinh pours some beer onto the ground at Huey's feet. A sm tear runs down his stoic face. Then CLICK. The blaster is abruptly turned off by Chuckie appears out of the shadows behind it. He stares a beat at Vinh like he can't believe what he's seeing. Vinh keeps on moving like he's in a trance.

What the fuck you doing? Vinh doesn't reply. Stares down at the ground, keeps on w his weird dance. Chuckie moves towards him. Tomas grabs Chuckie, tries to stop him from going for Vinh, but Chuck shrugs him off. Chuckie reaches out and shakes Vinh. No response. He shak him again.
I asked you what your deal is, sand dancer? The second shake sort of breaks Vinh out of his trance. H shivers.
It's a tribute. A gesture.
A what? Vinh stares down at the dirt at his feet.
Your brain even smaller than 'em slits for eyes? Vinh slouches defiantly over to the blaster and presses t 8 replay.
Keep on banging out that ghetto ass shit and you'll alert every cop in Podunk county.
It's for Huey. Our dead homie. The song starts again. Chuckie looks at him incredulously shouts above the music.
You checked out, right?
He loved that track. Vinh snorts back a sob. He hugs himself into a hunch and starts dancing again. Chuckie loses it. He slaps Vinh.
Get a grip, skippy. Vinh rubs his face. He's getting a grip all right. Chucki slams off the blaster.

Huey's DEAD. And ain't no requiem gonna resurrect his ass. He down under the ground now with the real men of respect. The three boys stand somberly in silence, each paying internal homage to their dead friend. Chuckie hardens his heart against the tears that threaten to flow. Tomas trembles, mumbles.
I didn't mean it. I didn't do it. I didn't mean to kill him. This breaks the moment. Chuckie snaps back.
Well he dead. That's it for him. OVER. But we still here. Hell, yeah. Payback's gonna be a real bitch for a real bitch. Vinh wipes away his tears.
She probably gone by now.
You best hope not, genius. She gone, we gone. Chuckie paces around the circumference of the clearing.

Della's been watching the scene unfold, a captive audienc attentive and terrified. Slowly she tears her eyes away from the boys. She backs a from the edge and right into the sharp branch of a big ol tree. The branch digs into that point in her shoulder she hurt earlier on the barbed wire. She reaches up to feel it and pulls her hand away bloody. reaches into her coat pockets for a tissue. Nothing. Feel something in her pants pocket. She pulls out not a tissue but a sheet of folded paper. She unfolds it. It's Tammi's drawing. The one from the beginning. The stick figure family holding hands and "Mommy - We lov you" written in stars. Della's lost in the drawing. Her eyes drink in every mark color and word. She sees that the male figure is slightly separate. That the children stick figures have frightened eyes and cling to the female. That the sky is turbulent. stars clear and bright. The words... A tear escapes from underneath her eyelid. Then another. sob. She might never see her kids again. Another sob. She heaves with the release of emotion. More tears escape. Another sob. She tries to bite it back Wills herself to stop. Finds that rage takes sorrow's place. Rage and self recrimination. Goddamit! She's gonna be raped and killed because of some stupid note! And God knows what will become of the kids. Kenneth always told her she had a temper. That she reacts without thinking of the consequences. This time the basta was right. She looks again at the picture. Chuckie's voice booms out into the night.

She folds the picture up carefully and puts it back in he pocket. Della edges further into the trees and disappears into th darkness. There's rustling in the darkness. Tomas pushes through th edge of the trees, making animal calls with his right han curled around his mouth. The flashlight illuminates him f behind. Chuckie follows him operating the light in a mockery of classic noir style. Vinh slouches behind them. Tomas heads along the ledge, straight past the spot where Della stood only moments before. Tomas doubles back. Thomas stops, sniffs.
I can smell her Bulgari. Chuckie's behind him surveying the area with the flashlig He finds several footprints by the tree.
She was right here. Must a saw your dumb ass tribute and everything. Vinh glares at Chuckie. Chuckie grins at Tomas.
Bulgari? She looks more like she rocks that number five shit.
It Bulgari, dude. My Dad's bitch bathes in it. Chuckie points the flashlight towards where the ledge end and a steep incline begins. 103
The flashlight illuminates a set of prints descending dow the incline.
There more of her footprints. Tomas and Vinh just stand like zombies. Chuckie pushes Vinh.

What you waiting on? Jackie Chan? Vinh plods clumsily down the incline, followed by Tomas. Chuckie sweeps the flashlight across the gulch looking fo sign of Della. Chuckie shifts his focus to climb down the steep slope. A the light sweeps back across the gulch we catch a glimpse Della between some rocks at the far side. But the boys' e are elsewhere, focused on the steep incline ahead of them Della quickly ducks, draws her toolbox in tight and crouc low between the rocks. She watches the boys carefully as climb down the gulch. There's the sound of a stumble followed by a splash.
What now, cabron?

Fell in a frozen ass stream. Chuckie sweeps the flashlight towards them. Della sees Vi trudging out of the stream, Tomas descending the last few feet of the other side of the gulch and Chuckie midway up Vinh jumps up and down trying to kick the water out of hi sneakers.
Zipperhead!
Kon'aro Kusotare.
You know we don't speak the Chinky.
What's your game, Chuckie? We left stumbling around in the dark while you hog the flashlight.
I stole it. I get to use it. That's how it works. That right Tomas?
Right on, dog. Chuckie jumps down from the last rock and joins Vinh and Tomas at the edge of the stream.
What if I steal it from you?
There you go, bro. He hands the flashlight over to Vinh. Vinh reaches for it Chuckie pulls it away.

April Fool. Naw, wait a minute, it ain't April. Must be Christmas fool. Tomas smirks. Vinh hangs his head down. They search for m prints, can't find any in the immediate area. Chuckie shi the flashlight at the foot of a big rock.
Her footprints disappear at the big rock. A beat. Della clutches the lug wrench in her right hand. Vinh shivers violently.

Head on up and search the slope. I'll guide your way with the flashlight. Chuckie sweeps the flashlight across the gulch. Della duc Della needs to get out of there and fast. They begin to ascend the rocks. Chuckie keeps the flashli slightly ahead of them. Della crawls stealthily between and behind the rocks, kee as low as she can. Dodging the approaching light. The boys crawl across and up and between the rocks with t dexterity of animals. Della's so low she's scraping her k and hands to shreds. She can see ahead where the rocks end and the trees begin What was she thinking hiding here? It was too exposed.

We gonna put yo ass on ice, bitch! God please help her make it back into the cover of the tr Della almost vomits. Her hand grasps the last rock at the top of the gulch. Sh pushes the toolbox up on the ledge. Her strength is ebbin but she tries to hoist herself up. The flashlight sweeps She lets go of the ledge and ducks. The flashlight sweeps again. She huddles in behind a rock. Waits a beat.
You going home in a casket tonight. Oh shit, they're approaching fast. She tries again to hoi herself up. She's almost up when the flashlight sweeps by again. This time, it catches her.

head_text.subj: THERE SHE IS, TOP OF THE GULCH

text: She practically throws herself over the ledge. Tomas scur to the top faster than lightening, catches her leg as she crawls from the edge. THUD. She kicks him in the face. Della grabs the toolbox. Makes a run for it.
Tomas falls back from the gulch-side, loosening several rocks. The rocks tumble downhill, hit Vinh.
Chuckie scales the gulch behind them. Vinh rubs his head. Sees something between the trees. Thinks it's Huey.
Huey? He starts towards the brush.
Is that you, homie? Chuckie catches up with Vinh, breathless from climbing fa Vinh points into the brush.
I saw Huey, there in the brush.
What? Chuckie looks around, hoping against hope that Vinh may b right, that Huey may just be alive. Vinh becomes perplexe
I saw him.
Sure you did, bro. Chuckie puts his arm around Vinh and helps him up the roc side. Vinh is shivering so hard he's almost sobbing. Just ahead Tomas pulls himself up and over the ledge. 104

Tomas catches up with Della, chases her into the trees. Behind him Vinh hoists himself up over the ledge, then Chuckie. Della runs. Faster than she's ever run before. Practicall flies through the trees. Her breath comes hard. His too, just behind her. Their footfalls crash into the foliage. It's dark, so dark. She's running blindly. And they're right behind her. Tomas swipes at her. He jus misses. He swipes again. A twisted shape looms ahead, almost blocks her path. She runs right up to it then darts left at the last momen setting up Thomas who's right behind her. Tomas runs into the stump of a big old tree trunk, hits himself at groin level. He doubles over in pain.
CONEJO! AIN'T NUTHIN' CAN SAVE YO ASS NOW.

Della races on. Thomas gathers himself together, picks up the chase. But that moment's delay has bought her some time. Her adrenaline pumps hard. Eyes darting for a hiding plac among the dark shapes and planes of the woods. 105

There it is, a deadwood pile. She throws herself down into its midst. The dried branche jag and tear at her hands and face. She burrows down low, low she's right in the dirt. She peers between the branch Tomas's feet run by and disappear. She hears him circle t area then turn back towards her. A moment passes. She picks the next. Rises slowly and sof from between the jagged branches clutching the lug wrench Scene 105Page 68

And then there he is. Diving out of the trees towards her Della raises the lug wrench. In the clouded moonlight it's an almost biblical image: a woman rising from the brush wielding an iron black cross. Tomas crashes towards her. Della swings the lug wrench, hard, intensely, directly at Tomas's face. There is a THUD as the sharp arm of the lug wrench catche him up under the chin. It sends him reeling. He goes down face first. Della gasps in horror, watches as: Tomas pulls himself up onto his feet, comes towards her o more. Della swings the lug wrench back and strikes him across t head. He spins, clutches at his head, then reaches towards her AGAIN. She loses it. She swings the lug wrench towards him.    A years of pent up rage finally find their release. The wrench catches up under his nose with a sickening CRU It drives the cartilage up and into his face. Blood spurts from the wound. He staggers backwards. A shocked scream escapes from Della's mouth.
Awwwrgh! As she staggers backwards in the opposite direction. Tomas tries to cry out but can only utter in pain.
Unnh! Unnh! Unnh! He tries to pull the lug wrench out of his face. Spins. Stumbles. The flashlight beam travels past them.

Unnh! Tomas crashes back into a tree. He loses consciousness. H body slumps slowly down the tree trunk to the dirt. Blood gushes from where the wrench meets his face. He looks lik he's dressed for Halloween. Della just stares. Stares at Tomas, at what she did, what had to do. Tomas' eyes are wide open, staring too, at nothing, dead. The horror of having killed someone overwhelms Della. She starts shaking with shock. Vinh cries out for Tomas
The sound of footfalls crashing through the brush follows
Curb the squealing. You a gangsta or a boy scout? Vinhs voice is breathless and jittery.

Tomas's gone, Chuckie. I can feel it. Della tears herself away from Tomas's body and staggers i the deadwood to collect the toolbox. It glints, even in t darkness. She grabs it and runs for cover behind a tree. Behind her in the near distance the chaotic sweeps of the flashlight illuminates Vinh and Chuckie as they march thr the woods searching for Tomas.

Tomas is one hard son of a bitch. He got her strung up from a tree by now and you know it. But Chuckie doesn't look so sure. Vinh charges ahead into darkness. Della flashes briefly into shot, running between the tree The flashlight sweeps by.
There's something over here. Chuckie walks towards Vinh. Vinh takes the flashlight fro Chuckie and shines it towards a thick shape between three trees.
It looks like a body. They close in on a muddle of shapes, bush and spidery tre trunks. The flashlight illuminates a tree trunk long and thick as a body.

It's a big old tree trunk, you paranoid gook. Chuckie tries to take the flashlight back from Vinh but V won't give it. Chuckie doesn't persist. Vinh keeps going, shivering and blustering. Vinh senses something. He shines the flashlight behind th tree trunk. Still nothing. Sweeps back. Della darts between the evergreens behind them. She conce herself in between the trunks and branches. Braces hersel waits for the right moments, the ones when they're not looking, to run between the trees. Cognizant enough to kn they just want to find Tomas right now. She seems to be o autopilot, becoming numb as the minutes stretch on. She watches Vinh plod forward and through the brush. He h every inch of it with the flashlight. Sighs. Doubles back follow Chuckie. Then, the flashlight catches a glimpse of something. Swee back, illuminates Tomas's dead body, splayed out on the m at the foot of the tree, eyes staring wide, bloody, ghast Tomas's Catholic cross pendant glimmers in the flashlight Silence until Vinh falls to his knees in front of Tomas, tries to speak but only a whisper comes out.

Tomas.....IYAH! Chuckie realizes from Vinh's demeanor that something real is wrong. He hesitates a moment, then rushes over to Vinh stares too at Tomas's body, gulps back the desire to scre He punches his fist hard into the tree behind Tomas' body instead. A shower of pine needles rains down on them. Chuckie grabs the flashlight and sweeps it away from the body, grabs Vinh's arm, grounding him. Vinh sobs and shakes.
She gonna kill you and me next. We're all gonna die here. God knows what other tools she got in that box.

It was a stupid ass accident killed Huey. You know that. And Tomas.... Chuckie chokes up despite himself. He stands up, brushes the pine needles off his tee shirt. He paces back and forth. He pulls the gun out from deep in his jeans. Della creeps between the trees behind them. She appears f second or two, like a ghost, behind the next tree. Chuckie defiantly fights back tears.
I promise you this. He kisses the gun.
This baby's gonna cancel her Christmas. Della darts between the trees, faster now. Their voices follow her.
Ain't no gun can kill a ghost gone bad. She staggers deeper and deeper into the forest, into the darkness.
You in America now, dude, where the ghosts bleed.
She hears a faint gurgle. She slows, listens. It's the burble of a stream.. She listens hard. Traces the sound. Treads towards it. There it is. Glistening, even in the dark. 106

She steps between rocks, walks straight into the stream below. She stands ankle deep in the icy water with her eyes clos clutching the toolbox. The water gurgles faintly below her, so cold it almost so like glass breaking. The ghastly images of what just happened play out behind eyes like an inerasable movie of the psyche to be remembe for all time. She's talking to herself in a whisper.
I'm sorry.
All she knows is that she just killed a boy. It may have in self defense but she killed him.
I'm so sorry!
The grief overcomes her silently. Her face crumples. Her stomach muscles spasm and wrack through her body. A grief deep tears would be a relief.
Where are you, God?
She falls to her knees in the stream. Holding herself and rocking. The freezing water seeps up into her clothes, he hair. Scene 106Page 73

Please, I just want to see my babies again. Her rocking slows until it stops. There's a loud crunch c by. She rises reflexively from the stream. Raises the toolbox. She looks around. A branch has broken from a tre and drags down into the stream behind her. This seems to bring her back to herself. She realizes it' only a matter of time before they come looking for her. S needs to get moving. She sets off downstream. She trudges through the shallow water. Her wet coat drags heavily. The stream must end somewhere, likely at the other edge o the woods. She trudges onwards, sweeping aside the branches of stoop trees, stepping around rocky obstacles in the stream. Forging ahead. She now needs to pee. GREAT. Her temper surges up. She looks for the right place to do it, realizes it's probably best to pee in the stream, so all trace of it wi be dispersed. A leafless willow trails its dried up branches into the stream. She makes her way toward it. She lays the toolbox down and disappears between the branches. We see glimpses of her lifting her coat, pullin down her pants, pushing the crotch of her underpants to t side. We hear her shiver and the faint tinkle of water meeting the stream. More glimpses of her pulling up her underpants and pants, smoothing down her coat. She hoists her coat up again around her waist and picks u the toolbox. She plows down stream once more. Longing to see the light that will tell her she's at the edge of the woods, closer the mall lights, closer to home. She swallows another wave of grief. The stream loops around ahead then splits into two. She follows it, picks the left fork. And then she hears it, the terrible sound of feet thunder down into the stream behind her. She doesn't even turn to see them. Just runs. Runs for he life. The glare of the flashlight blasts against her back. Free water splashes up her legs, soaking through her pants. He feet slip and slide over wet rocks. But she keeps running Vinh's behind her. She can feel his breath, the swipe of hands as he grabs for her and misses. She runs even faste She leaps over tree trunks that cross the stream. They le behind her. She pushes through the hanging branches of several trees. Pushes them forward hard then lets them go as she passes, right into Vinh's face. He tries to duck but they hit him right in the eyes. He c out, covers his eyes.

Aaaarrhh. This buys her a moment or two to get ahead. The stream be right ahead. She opts to stay in it. Chuckie leaps out, r along the banks, hoping to outrun and trap her. But the stream then bends left, giving her an advantage. leaps back across the stream to the other side. But she's outrunning him. He charges back into the stream behind he Della keeps on running through the stream, somehow trusti its direction. Vinh catches up with Chuckie. The boys are maybe twenty-f feet behind her. A SHOT rings out. Then a bullet races past her ear. Lodge a tree just ahead of her. She almost loses her footing. S forgotten for just a moment, that they had a gun. Another shot blasts off into the night, skims her shoulde hits the muddy bank of the stream. She flinches, braces herself, keeps going, adrenalin pumping harder than ever. The stream winds around a bunch of rocks ahead. For just moment she's invisible to them. She uses it. When she rea the rocks, she dives out, ducking below the glare of Chuckie's flashlight, down behind the rocks. 107

She creeps up the muddy embankment hiding deep in the sha of some wiry shrubs, as close to the mud as her back will allow. The boys stop by the rocks. Chuckie sweeps the flashlight the muddy embankment, looking for a footprint, a sign of She tries to creep through the midst of the brush to avoi leaving prints. Tries to stay quiet as a mouse. Stops whe she sees the flashlight sweep by. If she can get to the top, she can make another run for i All of a sudden, it grows dark. The boys must have switch the flashlight off or maybe the battery's dead. She liste hard for their footfalls. Nothing. 108

She sees that she is in the shadows of a big old Pine tre She creeps behind its massive gnarled trunk and silently slides open the toolbox, fumbles around for the screwdriv She removes it from the box and grasps it tight. Della rises slowly, remaining concealed behind the tree. reaches up and softly places the toolbox deep in the junc of the first sturdy branch and the tree trunk. She pulls herself up onto the branch and edges in close to the trun She peeks between the branches. No sign of the boys. She pulls herself further up into th tree, branch by branch. The thin stiff outer branches, fringed with sharp little needles, fall like a jagged veil around her. She waits. She's high enough up to have a clear view of the landscap below despite the darkness. She makes out the faint echo of voices, strains to hear. Scene 109Page 76
Vinh and Chuckie are arguing in whispers. Vinh's pale and shivering hard.
I don't feel good, Chuckie. You think I got the hypothermia?
Nah, yo got the yellow fever. Vinh sulks.
I'm telling you, it ain't natural how she gets away every time. Chuckie clicks the flashlight back on. Sweeps it up, acro and back down the embankment to the stream, illuminating banks.

She got to be hiding up on the slope? You head up first and I'll follow with the flashlight. The light sweeps past her. Della shrinks further into the branches of the tree. She crunches her foot against a bra
The boys freeze, then resume talking in whispers.
I ain't going up there without the gun. End of story.
Never would've pegged you as a pussy, Vinh. Even when Huey and Tomas called it, I always defended your ass.
Ain't no one never said I was a pussy.
She a skinny ass bitch, too. Can't be weighing in at more than one twenty. Scene 109Page 77
Tomas an Huey never called me a pussy.
I ain't speaking ill o' the dead.
You already did. Vinh's shivering so hard his teeth are knocking.
Anyways, when you ever shot a gun? Probably miss and shoot yourself in the foot. Vinh paces, braces himself to head up after Della. 110
Vinh starts to ascend the embankment.
That's the spirit gangsta. Holler if you see her and I'll shoot. Vinh glares back at Chuckie.

Faito! Della watches Vinh plough through the brush. The flashlight sweeps and darts with his movements, up ah of him, up the embankment. Vinh pushes through several trees, slips, regains his footing. He plods past the tree. She slips the screwdrive her sleeve. Prays he won't stop. She pulls herself further up the tree. A sudden commotion of swaying branches startles her, foll by a shower of pine needles. Her heart stops. A moment later the sound of fluttering wings is followed the squawking of angry birds. She's disturbed a bird's nest. Scene 110Page 78

She sees the silhouette of four large crows as they burst through the branches above and up into the patch of sky between. The crows circle the patch of sky above, like a Greek cho She looks back down for a sign of Vingh. Sees nothing. In along a branch to see better. The light sweeps back and up through the trees into her e line, disorienting her. She hears footfalls so close by they must be under the tr Her eyes have barely readjusted when she sees him: Vinh standing under the tree scanning the area for a sign of h She stares down at him, frozen, holding her breath. The flashlight illuminates the whole tree, then sweeps aw up the embankment. But Vinh's seen something. He makes out her footprints un the tree. He leans down to check, then rises, looks up through the branches. Their eyes meet. He opens his mouth to shout for Chuckie. She LEAPS down through the branches. Lands THUD on his ba
She silences his yell with a choke hold. Wraps her legs around his torso. He bites her arm but she holds tight.
Vinh? Panic has crept into Chuckie's voice.

Vinh topples to the mud, dragging Della with him. They roll as he desperately tries to disengage her. The flashlight frantically searches the area for them. Della frees the screwdriver she'd stuffed up her sleeve. She DRIVES the screw driver up into the base of Vinh's sk Vinh screams. She thrusts and twists the tool. All the while she's tightly wound around him, intertwined intimate as a lover. She drives the screw driver deeper in until she feels her knuckles dig into his stiff hair. Vinh's scream becomes a high keening wail. The screwdriver pierces the base of Vinh's skull. It protrudes through his mouth, knocking several teeth out i stream of blood. His scream cracks into a death rattle as hers begins. They roll downstream. His arms are wrapped in a death grip around her. They roll until they crash full into a tree about two thi of the way down. She feels his grip loosen and his body slump over hers. H becomes so heavy he almost crushes her underneath as he d right there on top of her. She's trapped, suffocating underneath him, until she find the strength to push him off. She crawls out from under his body. Pushing him away, sets him off rolling again. She tries to stand up but her legs are unsteady. Her head hurts so bad it's about to burst. The world around her shifts into a migraine zone. Trails follow trees, rocks, brush. The desire to close her eyes, close it all out almost overwhelms her. Her shoulder aches too and there's a new pain in her arm where Vinh bit her. She sees blood has matted her sleeve, rolls it up to find a nasty bite mark. There's a loud crash. Della freezes and moves only her ey looks around. It's Vinh's body hitting the stream below. Where was the light at the edge of the woods? Nowhere to seen now that's for sure. She staggers along the slope, clutching onto tree trunks roots as she goes. Della grabs for a shrub to help her cross a patch of mudd slope. Pulls it clean out by the roots. Loses her footing reaches for the roots of an old tree. She pulls herself u Plods once more along the slope, heading upwards in a diagonal through the darkness. She arrives at the top of the slope only to be met by mor darkness. But there's a strange calm about her now. Like she's reached the eye of a terrible storm.
Della?

When she hears his voice drifting faintly towards her, sh almost smiles. She knows he's coming for her and there's nothing she can about it. Della shivers as she sees a surreal tableau ahead: four h felled trees wrapped in white plastic. Their sad stumps a only feet away. It's the funeral parlour of the forest.
Delllaaa?

Della sinks down behind the large trunk of a plastic wrap tree. She listens hard, tries to fathom which direction h coming from. His voice drifts in and out of proximity like he's pacing around in circles. His voice has changed - he's dropped t gangster schtick.
There's only you and me, now.
